channel.title: SimbaInterception (OpenGL plugin) Lastest Release: 11-12-2011 [Github]
channel.description:
[b]About:[/b] SimbaInterception has become my interest of late after the bot nuke I wanted to learn more how openGL bots work, and inevitably I am now also learning some basic's in C++. I would like to take a moment and thank benland, silentwolf, and the team that wrote GL_Intercept for releasing source code as without it I would not know where to begin with openGL (GLIntercept), or figure out in a million years how to create a Simba Plugin (Smart source), also the stride details silentwolf once found was a great starting place. even if now identifying a model type by its stride is not enough. Originally I wanted to write this to work with a java application using JNI but I suck and JNI is too difficult for my tiny mind to grasp. So I decided to make it work with Simba FIRST, I may go back to making it work with JNI later. At this time I would like to point out that my experience in C++ is about 5 days of mucking about so these files may not be cross platform and are probably highly detectable.
[b]Function List:[/b]
[ul][li]InterceptionGetDebug() : boolean - returns the current plugin debug state[/li] [li]function InterceptionGetViewport(var x,y,width,height : integer) : boolean - sets x,y,width,height and returns if it could access the viewport or not[/li][/ul]
[b]Procedure List:[/b]
[ul][li]InterceptionSetOverlay(b: boolean) - sets the GLWrapper overlay state[/li] [li]InterceptionSetDebug(d: boolean) - sets the Plugin Debug State[/li] [li]procedure InterceptionGetGLPosition(x,y : integer; var posX,posY,posZ : double) - get your mouseclicks position in the GL scene[/li] [li]procedure InterceptionSetUsingResizeableClient(b: boolean) - due to the way the chat windows renders over the gl scene on the fixedsize client I have implemented this setting for position calculations. BY DEFAULT THE WRAPPER ASSUMES YOU ARE USING THE FIXED CLIENT SETTING. if you are using the other you need to change this setting or your position calculations will be wrong.[/li] [li]procedure GetModelPositionByChecksum(id :integer; var x,y : integer) - Returns the position of a model if found searching for the model checksum (red text on model when overlay is on)[/li] [li]procedure InterceptionGetModelPositionByTriCount(triCount :integer; var x,y : integer); - Allows you to get find onscreen models by the triangle count.[/li][/ul]
[b]GLWrapper Commands:[/b] at anytime while running the client with the openGL wrapper you can execute these commands:
[ul][li]VK_HOME - toggles overlay[/li] [li]VK_F1 - sets the search stride to 12 (once designated for mobile entity, However you will quickly see that this method is not enough and will require review [/li] [li]VK_F2 - VK_F7 - other available search strides [/li] [li]F8 - will display model details for all models on screen. (high detail enjoy your wall of text)[/li] [li]Page up - while the debug overlay is on will switch what is displayed on your screen, currently from modelChecksum to modelTriangleCount[/li][/ul]
[b]Easy Installation:[/b] (its been brought up a few times but this step is not nessesary, you can place the openGL wrapper in the JVM bin and use your browser/Smart if so desired)
[ol][li]Download the runescape client installer & install the Runescape client[/li] [li]Place the openGLWrapper (opengl32.dll) in the runescape client bin folder (for me was found: C:\Documents and Settings\silabsoft\jagexcache\jagexlauncher\bin)[/li] [li]Place the Simba Plugin in the designated Simba plugin directory[/li] [li]set the client graphics to openGL[/li][/ol]
[b]Downloads[/b]
[ol][li]http://uppit.com/nad6bve8icbf/SimbaInterception-11-7-2011.zip[/li][/ol]
Sample Script: [code=pascal]program plugintest; {$Loadlib SimbaInterception}
begin writeln(InterceptionGetDebug()); InterceptionSetOverlay(true); end. [/code]
[IMG]http://i.imgur.com/T0a7c.png[/img]
[b]What's Next:[/b] want to make position calculations pick any position of the model, and have a few other choices when it comes to searching for a model, such as String Name (someones going to have to be awesome and make the database) vertex count and so on.
[b]Github:[/b] https://github.com/silabsoft/SimbaGL .

item.title: SimbaInterception (OpenGL plugin) Lastest Release: 11-12-2011 [Github]
item.dc:creator: @Wolf Wolf
item.description:
@Wolf wrote:

Aftermath:

You have to have RuneScape running in OpenGL mode with the modified DLL before running the script. Simba’s plugin error messages are terribly misinformative.

Ah yeah that’s a good point. I’ll try that out here later and I’ll let ya know how it goes. Thanks for the suggestion, Aftermath.

Edit:
Yes you were right, I have it working fine now. Time to develop.

Edit2:
Now all we need is a way to grab the color data from the client so the rest of the SRL Include can function. Aftermath (or Silabsoft), by chance would you be able to create an in-game text-reader or OCR to work with OGL? I’m quite sure it’s out of my league to attempt…

Read full topic

item.title: SimbaInterception (OpenGL plugin) Lastest Release: 11-12-2011 [Github]
item.dc:creator: @Wolf Wolf
item.description:
@Wolf wrote:

Silabsoft, if it means anything to you this is what the debug window says when the plugin is included in Simba:

Starting Interception 0.2
Could not create file mapping object
Interception finalized!

And apparently this is caused in the Main.cpp in this boolean:

{
HANDLE hMapFile;
hMapFile = OpenFileMappingA(
                   FILE_MAP_ALL_ACCESS, // read/write access
                   FALSE, // do not inherit the name
                   szSharedMemoryName); // name of mapping object
if (hMapFile == NULL)
{
cout << "Could not create file mapping object \n";
return false;
}
pCommands = (DWORD *)MapViewOfFile(hMapFile, // handle to map object
FILE_MAP_ALL_ACCESS, // read/write permission
0,
0,
255);
if (pCommands == NULL)
{
cout << "Could not map view of file (%d). \n";
CloseHandle(hMapFile);
return false;
}
cout << "Running Interception \n";
return true;
}

I’m really hoping you have an idea on why the “OpenFileMappingA” is failing.

Read full topic

item.title: SimbaInterception (OpenGL plugin) Lastest Release: 11-12-2011 [Github]
item.dc:creator: @Wizzup Wizzup?
item.description:
@Wizzup wrote:

The Simba plugin changes are backwards compatible. But not forward compatible. That is, if you make one for the new ABI it won’t work with the old ABI, obviously.

I’ve documented it here. http://docs.villavu.com/simba/simbaref/plugins.html

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Wolf Wolf
item.description:
@Wolf wrote:

I might be missing a step here, but Simba isn’t finding the ‘SimbaInterception’ plugin. Infact, when I try compiling even just your simple example script I get the error: “Exception in Script: Plugin(SimbaInterception32) has not been found”. I even renamed your plugin to “SimbaInterception32” and still no success. I have both ‘SimbaInterception.dll’ and ‘opengl32.dll’ in my Simba’s Plugins folder, as well as ‘opengl32.dll’ in my Windows32 folder.

Any advice/suggestions?

Read full topic

item.description:
@silabsoft wrote:

well I guess that covers sending arrays from pascal to C++ I am forced to have the length as a parameter which I would prefer over a null termination. However I still have the problem of sending the arrays back to pascal. any suggestions?

item.title: SimbaInterception (OpenGL plugin) Lastest Release: 11-12-2011 [Github]
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

technically, if you have a static C-array (think “int test[9001]”, not C99’s variable-lengthed arrays) you can use the sizeof operator to get the size of the array…as such:

int dick[512];
print("%d", sizeof(dick) / sizeof(int));

regardless, this wouldn’t work with the pascal to cpp data type conversion since it’s done at runtime…i was just correcting aftermath since he seemed to imply that it’s not possible at all in cpp

Read full topic

item.title: SimbaInterception (OpenGL plugin) Lastest Release: 11-12-2011 [Github]
item.dc:creator: @Aftermath_961 Aftermath
item.description:
@Aftermath_961 wrote:

[quote=“Miss Silabsoft, post:54, topic:420887”]the problem I was running into from pascal to c++ was I could not get the length. If I knew the length it was fine but I can’t accept doing something like arary, int length) for procedures.

the problem I had passing arrays back to Pascal as they had always returned empty even though in C++ they contained data.

Most likely this is all due to my inexperience with C++[/quote]

You have to do array, length for procedures [or otherwise pass the length] (regarding Pascal to C++)… this is the nature of C++. An array is not an object with a length property as in Java, but just a pointer with convenient offsetting in possibly multiple dimensions. The only ways you know the length of an array or data starting at a pointer is either 1) passing the length as a parameter explicitly 2) passing it just before the pointer, as Wizzup mentioned 3) terminating the data with the NUL character, as in the case of zero-terminated strings.

If you look into the various implementations of strings in C++ libraries, they use either 2), 3), or a combination of the two. 1) is used for example in main for a standalone program - the argument count is passed to you. This is the nature of C/++.

Read full topic

item.title: SimbaInterception (OpenGL plugin) Lastest Release: 11-12-2011 [Github]

the problem I had passing arrays back to Pascal as they had always returned empty even though in C++ they contained data.

Most likely this is all due to my inexperience with C++

Read full topic

item.title: SimbaInterception (OpenGL plugin) Lastest Release: 11-12-2011 [Github]
item.dc:creator: @sspoke sspoke
item.description:
@sspoke wrote:

You don’t need to know how to read pascal array in c++. just make the parameter to integer value (pointer value) in c++ like

__declspec (dllexport) void FindModelByIds(int ptrArrayTest){
   add_log("blah = %x", ptrArrayTest);
}

Since when you call a function in C++ it would pass each parameter as 32bit value anyways…

Then try some random guessing… if array elements are all 4 bytes each correct? then you can try

__declspec (dllexport) void FindModelByIds(int ptrArrayTest){
   add_log("blah = %x", ptrArrayTest);
   add_log("blah 4 bytes in = %x", *(DWORD *)ptrArrayTest+4);
   add_log("blah 8 bytes in = %x", *(DWORD *)ptrArrayTest+8);
   add_log("blah 12 bytes in = %x", *(DWORD *)ptrArrayTest+12);
   add_log("blah 16 bytes in = %x", *(DWORD *)ptrArrayTest+16);
}

So maybe 8 bytes in… might be the first element in the array. read the outputs and compare to scar script values. Then again you might not find it, it might be that the values are not values but references… so you can de-reference those values like…

int value1 = *(DWORD *)ptrArrayTest //Lets say ptrArrayTest holds a value thats a reference (another point) 

int value2 = *(DWORD *)value1; //Now you got the value of that reference.

Like I said it’s all guess work and not too hard. Unless the pascal array is encrypted… then you may have some difficulties, otherwise there is probably a write up somewhere on the structure of pascal arrays.

Read full topic
